docs.abstract: Richard Klein Op-Ed article on report by Food and Drug Administration of 33 instances of abnormalities in heart valves of women taking diet drugs fenfluramine and phentermine; says perhaps diet drugs should have stricter FDA approval that takes their potential for abuse into account; says real problem is that doctors see obesity as epidemic, and their drumbeat of dire warnings have overwhelmed issue of whether treatment is more dangerous than disease it is intended to cure; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: According to the Food and Drug Administration, there have been 33 reports of abnormalities in the heart valves of women who had been taking the diet drugs fenfluramine and phentermine. But the F.D.A. has made clear it has no plans right now to do any more than warn doctors and consumers of the possible side effects. In the case of other medications, that course might be enough to insure that doctors and patients act responsibly. But when it comes to a culturally sensitive area like weight, the widespread use of diet drugs is unlikely to stop. Perhaps diet drugs should have a stricter F.D.A. approval process that takes their potential for abuse into account.

headline.main: The Fearful Price of Getting Thin

docs.abstract: Sad history of dangerous and ineffective obesity treatments reviewed in light of disclosure of threat posed by diet drug combination fen-phen (fenfluramine and phentermine); drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: COULD it be the revenge of the fat cells? For decade after decade, the overweight have been seeking a magic bullet. And every time they thought they had found one, it turned out to be useless or even dangerous. From an industrial poison to hormones to amphetamines to the latest craze, the drug combination known as fen-phen, the search for a way to melt off pounds has known no respite.

headline.main: 2 Popular Diet Pills Linked to Problems With Heart Valves

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration warns doctors to monitor patients taking popular diet pill combination for heart problems in wake of report by doctors at Mayo Clinic and at Fargo, ND, clinic that they found very rare heart valve ailment in 24 previously healthy women taking pills and potentially fatal constriction of arteries to lungs in eight affected women; women were taking fenfluramine and phentermine, or fen-phen; FDA has never approved drug combination, but has approved each drug for use by itself, for short periods of time, to treat severe obesity; mildly overweight people have been taking drugs, many for long periods; New England Journal of Medicine, which was set to publish report in August, allows prepublication publicity because of potential importance to public health (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., and at a medical clinic in Fargo, N.D., said yesterday that a very rare heart ailment had appeared in 24 women who took a popular diet pill combination. Their report has prompted the Food and Drug Administration to send warnings to thousands of doctors. The women, all previously healthy, were taking fenfluramine and phentermine, or fen-phen, a popular combination of diet pills, when they developed an unusual and serious heart valve problem. Eight of them also had a potentially fatal condition in which the arteries that supply blood to the lungs constrict.

headline.main: Adult Diabetes Type on Rise in Young

docs.abstract: Researchers find dramatic increase in incidence of adult-onset, or Type 2, diabetes among young patients, especialy black children, at Arkansas Children's Hospital; patients with Type 2 diabetes are generally obese and have family history of the disease; nearly all children with Type 2 diabetes are obese (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The type of diabetes that usually strikes fat adults appears to be on the rise among children. Researchers reported in the July issue of the journal Pediatrics that they had found a dramatic increase in the incidence of Type 2 diabetes among young patients, especially black children, at the Arkansas Children's Hospital.
